sentences.sentence: In July, Canada's unemployment rate held steady at 4.9 per cent(https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/n1/daily-quotidien/220805/dq220805a-eng.htm?HPA=1), matching the historic low recorded in June and leading some to suggest(https://www.ctvnews.ca/business/here-s-why-experts-say-canada-isn-t-headed-for-a-recession-1.5957949) Canada is safe from a recession.

But while low unemployment potentially indicates a tight labour market, it doesn't preclude a recession.First, the unemployment rate can fall for two reasons - either potential workers are finding work, which is positive, or potential workers are dropping out of the labour force and no longer looking for work, which is usually negative.

The unemployment rate was unchanged from June to July but that hid a small decline(https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/t1/tbl1/en/tv.action?pid=1410028701) in the labour force and a small increase(https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/t1/tbl1/en/tv.action?pid=1410028701) in the number of unemployed Canadians.The unemployment rate is clearly not as simple as it seems.
It's also a lagging indicator, meaning it doesn't usually rise until after an economic downturn has already begun.Why is that?
Imagine you're a business owner.
As the economy starts to slow, your sales decline.
The normal response is to reduce costs not directly tied to production and marketing.
You might also haul back on bonuses but you generally try to avoid laying off workers you've invested in and trained.
As the slowdown continues and sales drop further, you may reduce worker hours but still try to avoid actual layoffs.

Eventually, you may have no choice but to let go workers.But that normally happens later in the recession, which is why the unemployment rate has traditionally lagged the economy by anywhere between six and 12 months and therefore is not the best indicator of how well the economy is performing.

So we should enjoy today's record low unemployment rate while we have it but also recognize that things may look quite different if and when the economic downturn finally forces employers to act.Nor is Canada's labour market as strong as the unemployment rate suggests.
A recent study published by the Fraser Institute found that the overall employment rate hasn't yet recovered to the pre-COVID levels of 2019.
In the past two months, moreover, it may actually have fallen(https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/t1/tbl1/en/tv.action?pid=1410028702) even further.

These lower employment rates mean that, despite our record-setting unemployment rate, a smaller share of the working-age population is at work than was the case before COVID.Matthew Lau: Anti-monopolists should focus on government(https://financialpost.com/opinion/matthew-lau-anti-monopolists-should-focus-on-government)Allan Lanthier: Four reasons our tax rules are a mess(https://financialpost.com/opinion/alan-lanthier-four-reasons-our-tax-rules-are-a-mess)Walter E. Block: Should we protect farmland?

(https://financialpost.com/opinion/walter-e-block-should-we-protect-farmland)In addition to these complexities in the labour market, there are other important considerations when assessing the risk of a recession.Inflation, the topic on everyone's mind, is one.
The latest year-over-year inflation number (for July) was 7.6 per cent(https://www.statcan.gc.ca/en/subjects-start/prices_and_price_indexes/consumer_price_indexes), following 8.1 per cent in June.

Because wages haven't been keeping up with these 40-year inflation highs, Canadians have less real purchasing power, which is bound to put a damper on consumer spending, which in turn is likely to slow economic growth.Moreover, to combat inflation the Bank of Canada hiked(https://www.bankofcanada.ca/2022/07/fad-press-release-2022-07-13/#:~:text=Press-,Bank%20of%20Canada%20increases%20policy%20interest%20rate,basis%20points%2C%20continues%20quantitative%20tightening&;text=The%20Bank%20of%20Canada%20today,the%20deposit%20rate%20at%202%C2%BD%25. )
its benchmark interest rate by a full percentage point in July, the largest increase in more than 20 years and the fourth time the Bank has raised interest rates since March, with more likely coming.
Higher interest rates increase the cost of borrowing, reduce demand and ultimately slow the economy.Already there are signs things are cooling.

Following a 0.3 per cent expansion in April, the economy experienced no growth in May and is expected(https://financialpost.com/news/economy/canada-gdp-what-economists-say) to grow just 0.1 per cent growth in June - not exactly encouraging numbers.A record low unemployment rate is good news, but it's just one indicator of the state of our economy.
Despite the tight labour market we may still be headed for a recession.Tegan Hill and Alex Whalen are policy analysts with the Fraser Institute.
@COPYRIGHT=© 2022 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly uncertain about this document. The writing style and content are not particularly AI-like.
